Friday Night Bluegrass returns to Music Barn

Gary Brewer is bringing high-level bluegrass back to the Shepherdsville Music Barn

Friday Night Bluegrass returns to Music Barn

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 1:16 p.m. EST November 4, 2014

Gary Brewer and The Kentucky Ramblers will host high-level bluegrass shows at the Shepherdsville Music Barn. (Photo: Provided )

Story Highlights

  • Friday Night Bluegrass at Shepherdsville Music Barn
  • WHEN: 8 p.m. Friday
  • WHERE: Shepherdsville Music Barn, 1833 Hwy. 44 W.
  • COST: $12
CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The Shepherdsville Music Barn has been a destination for fans of country and bluegrass music since 1977, and is part of a tradition with much deeper roots.

In America, barn dances date back to the 1800s and were a hotbed of country and bluegrass music in the 1920s and '30s. Fans of legends such as Bill Monroe and Ralph Stanley would flock to barns and school gymnasiums to see their heroes, and the shows were vital community events.

In recent years, the Shepherdsville Music Barn's Friday night bluegrass shows have fallen on hard times, but that's about to change. Louisville bluegrass impresario Gary Brewer has taken over Friday nights beginning this week, and isn't messing around.

Now through April, he'll feature the likes of Doyle Lawson & Quicksilver, The Isaacs, Russell Moore and IIIyrd Tyme Out, Claire Lynch, Larry Sparks and The Lonesome Ramblers, The Larry Stephenson Band and Michael Cleveland and Flamethrower.

CONCERTS: Taylor Swift coming to Louisville

"I'm using my 35 years of rubbing shoulders and performing with all of these guys to get them in there and try and build the Barn back up again," Brewer said, "and I think we're on the right route."

The Crowe Brothers will kick off Brewer's run Friday night at the Shepherdsville Music Barn, right off of Interstate 65 at 1833 Ky. 44 W. It's a 500-capacity room with theater seating and a family agenda, which means no alcohol.

Brewer and various incarnations of his Kentucky Ramblers have been playing traditional bluegrass for decades, and his earliest bands got some of their first exposure at the Shepherdsville Music Barn. His grandfather, Finley J. Brewer Sr., was a member of the Carter Family's band — they were only the first family of country music.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Rancid recaptures its punk glory on new LP

The Ramblers play as many as 300 dates a year and have a new album called "Homestretch" featuring sons Mason and Wayne, father Finley and Larry Beasley. Finley Brewer will emcee the Friday night concerts in Shepherdsville, and the Kentucky Ramblers will open every show while sticking around for jam sessions if the headliner is in the mood.

"We want to make it more of a show experience rather than just a performance by the headliners," said Brewer, who for years organized Louisville's Strictly Bluegrass Festival. "You want to entertain people because that's what keeps them coming back."

Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.

Friday Night Bluegrass at Shepherdsville Music Barn

WHEN: 8 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Shepherdsville Music Barn, 1833 Hwy. 44 W.

COST: $12
